text:
Situation A. Dewayne's and Jorge's Product Game Board

Dewayne's markers are on 16, 18, and 28.

Jorge's markers are on 14, 21, and 30.

The paper clips are on 5 and 6.

It is Dewayne's tun to move a paper clip.

  1. What moves can Dewayne make?
  2. Which moves do you think he should make? Explain.
  3. Dewayne says he is looking for products that can be expressed as either 5N or 6N. Does this make sense? Explain.

1. Dewayne could move the paper clip on 5 to any number 1-9 except 5, or he could move the paper clip on 6 to any number 1-9 except for 6. If he moves the "5" paperclip:6 x 1 = 6, 6 x 2 = 12, 6 x 4 = 24, 6 x 6 = 36, 6 x 7 = 42, 6 x 8 = 48, 6 x 9 =54. If he moves the "6" paperclip: 5 x 1 = 5, 5 x 2 = 10, 5 x 3 = 15, 5 x 4 = 20, 5 x 5 = 25, 5 x 7 = 35; 5 x 8 = 40; 5 x 9 = 45.
  2. Student answer may vary. For example: I think Dewayne should move the paper clip from 5 to 7 so that he can both block Jorge and get three markers in a row. To get three markers in a row, Dewayne would have to land on 15 (move from 6 to 3), 20 (move from 6 to 4), 9 (not possible), 42 (move from 5 to 7), 7 (not possible), or 45 (move from 6 to 9). To block Jorge from getting 4 in a row. Dewayne would have to land on 42. To do this, he should move the paper clip from 5 to 7.
  3. He could be checking out multiples of 5 on the game board (5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, 40, 45) or multiples of 6 on the board (6, 12, 18 [already covered], 24, 30 [already covered], 36, 42, 48, 54, 72).

Situation B. Hank's New Game: Algebra Connections

Hank is excited about using the algebraic expression 3N to express multiples of 3. So he makes up a new game, Algebra Connections. He write clues with algebraic expression or equations involving factors and multiples. The players take turns deciding if there is one number, more than one number, or no number that makes the expression or equation true.

Hank says, "I am thinking of a whole number N. Here is the clue. What is N?"

  • What answers would Hank write on the back of each card?
At this point, expect students to guess and check numbers for N to make each statement true.

For 3N to be even, N must have a factor of 2. So any even number will work.

2, 4, 6, 8, 10...

3 ⋅ 2 = 6, so 3N = 6 (even number

3 ⋅ 4 = 12, so 3N = 12 (even number

3 ⋅ 6 = 18, so 3N = 18 (even number

Students might think of this as the multiples of 3 that are even numbers.

If N is odd, the product of 3 ⋅ N would be an odd number.

1, 3, 5, 7, 9,...

3 ⋅ 1 = 3, so 3N = 3 (odd number)

3 ⋅ 3 = 9, so 3N = 9 (odd number)

3 ⋅ 5 = 15, so 3N = 15 (odd number)

Students might think of this as multiples of 3 that are odd numbers.

To have 3N < 3, the only whole number to make this statement true is 0.

3(0) < 3

N = 1

A prime number only has two factors: 1 and itself.

Because 3 is already a factor 3N, the only other factor of 3N must be 1.

3 ⋅ 1 = 3

Students might think of this as the only multiple of 3 that is prime.

N can be any whole number that is not 0 or 1.

Or N is all whole numbers equal to or greater than 2.

For example, 3 ⋅ 2 = 6, and 6 is a composite number. 3 ⋅ 3 = 9, and 9 is a composite number.

A composite number has more than two factors. Because 3 is already a factor of 3N , we just need N to have at least two factors.

N might be 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, or 12.

The factors os 36 are

1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 9, 12, 18, 36.

3N must equal one of those factors.

To get those factors:

3 ⋅ some whole number ≠ 1

3 ⋅ some whole number ≠ 2

3 ⋅ 1 = 3

3 ⋅ some whole number ≠ 4

3 ⋅ 2 = 6

3 ⋅ 3 = 9

3 ⋅ 4 = 12

3 ⋅ 6 = 18

3 ⋅ 12 = 36
